posts._title: Agnieszka Holland – Aktorzy prowincjonalni aka Provincial Actors (1979)
posts.title: Aktorzy prowincjonalni
posts.excerpt: Talented Polish director Agnieszka Holland who would be better known in later years because of her films like Europa, Europa (1991) or some of her American works like Washington Square (1997), hits the mark early and again with this ostensible story about provincial actors in Poland. In reality, the comedy-drama can be read as a …

posts._title: René Vautier – Avoir 20 ans dans les Aurès AKA To Be Twenty in the Aures (1972)
posts.title: Avoir 20 ans dans les Aurès
posts.excerpt: Summary In 1961, a group of pacifist Bretons are sent to fight in France’s war against Algeria. Reluctant warriors, they are moulded into killing machines by the inspirational lieutenant Perrin and soon find their first taste of conflict. One of the group continues to rebel against the folly of the war and goes on the …
posts.titleEnglish: To Be Twenty in the Aures

posts.title: Lautarii
posts.excerpt: Leader of a traveling gypsy band from the steppes of Bessarabia (now Moldova), Toma Alistar is a skilled violinist whose fame takes him on tours around European capitals and royal courts. He remains obsessed with his first love, beautiful Leanca who was married elsewhere while Toma was traveling, and spends his life and fortune trying …

posts._title: Nikos Papatakis – Gloria mundi aka Tortura (1976)
posts.title: Gloria mundi
posts.excerpt: The young actress Galai is hired by his friend and director Hamdias to interpret a film denouncing the torture of suspected terrorists during the war of Algeria. The woman, using audio recordings made during the torture, practices the worst violence on herself to make her own interpretation as realistic as possible, to confuse reality with …

posts.title: Suspect
posts.excerpt: A group of British boffins have their humanitarian research classified by the Government. Unhappy with the decision, some fume, some grumble and some may just be ripe for picking by a sinister spy ring. Nigel Balchin back in the Small Back Room territory, minus Michael Powell.

posts.title: Begotten
posts.excerpt: Description: God disembowels himself with a straight razor. The spirit-like Mother Earth emerges, venturing into a bleak, barren landscape. Twitching and cowering, the Son Of Earth is set upon by faceless cannibals.

posts._title: F. Hugh Herbert – Scudda Hoo! Scudda Hay! (1948)
posts.title: Scudda Hoo! Scudda Hay!
posts.excerpt: Plot:Though the title sounds like something from a Big Band era tune, it actually refers to commands used during the training of mules. Young Snug Dominy has just purchased a pair of strapping mules. With no available cash, he must work for their previous owner to pay them off. Snug lives with his callous stepmother …

posts._title: Anne-Sophie Birot – Les Filles ne Savent pas Nager aka Girls Can’t Swim (2000)
posts.title: Les Filles ne Savent pas Nager
posts.excerpt: Quote: Even though they grew up in opposite parts of France, Gwen (Isild Le Besco) and Lise (Karen Alyx) are best friends and spend every summer vacation together on the Brittany coast where Gwen lives and Lise’s family has a summer home. But this summer is different because Lise’s family isn’t going on vacation for …

posts.title: Matzor
posts.excerpt: Quote: The issue of War widow representation in Israeli cinema is one of the most complex for the local industry for it seems to be unique and with a very local and specific iconography. The war Widow is a difficult character to digest. Because this is an especially painful topic in Israel, its mode of …

posts._title: Rudolf Thome – Rote Sonne aka Red Sun (1970)
posts.title: Rote Sonne
posts.excerpt: Rote Sonne aka Red Sun Rudolf Thome, Germany 1970 Runtime: 85 min Language: German “… one of the best German movies since the silent era … “ Dark and zany, Rote Sonne provides a fascinating snapshot of 60s culture, juxtaposing the B-film crime and science fiction genres with early feminist fervor.
